required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020

clinical_study.brief_title: Reducing Adverse Delivery Outcomes Through Teleneonatology: A Feasibility Study
clinical_study.official_title: Reducing Adverse Delivery Outcomes Through Teleneonatology: A Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: More infants die in Alabama every year than the majority of other states in the United States. Some of these deaths may occur at delivery due to providers with limited experience with neonatal resuscitation performing the resuscitation. Using low-cost telecommunications technology or telemedicine (similar to FaceTime), a highly trained neonatologist in one part of the state can assist the providers with resuscitating a baby in another part of the state. However, few studies have compared resuscitation in person to resuscitation through telemedicine. This randomized trial will evaluate teleneonatology in a simulated environment by comparing resuscitation performance of trainees with and without the aid of teleneonatology.

detailed_description.textblock:
Multiple studies have evaluated telemedicine using simulation1-3 but the level of evidence is low. In a previous simulation study wherein pediatric residents and respiratory therapists were assigned to either bedside resuscitation or video assisted resuscitation facilitated by a neonatologist, the time to effective ventilation was decreased in the video assisted resuscitation group. However, providers were not randomized and more providers in the bedside resuscitation group were at a lower level of training and had attended fewer neonatal resuscitations. Additionally, the facilitating neonatologists were aware of the clinical scenario limiting the study's generalizability to real time teleneonatology.1 In this proposal randomization of care providers will reduce selection bias between resuscitation arms, facilitators of teleneonatal resuscitation will be blinded to clinical scenarios, and bedside resuscitation by an experienced provider will be compared to teleneonatal resuscitation.
Integration of telemedicine into clinical care is highly resource dependent. It requires real time, high fidelity communication with a low failure rate at multiple sites as well as rapid connectivity given the time sensitivity of neonatal resuscitation. Previous feasibility studies using teleneonatology reported audio and video quality unusable to nearly 20% of consultations.4 Another study comparing different telemedicine technologies found lower reliability and audio-video quality with wireless tablets compared to a wired cart.5 Given the multitude of logistical considerations, this proposal will further evaluate teleneonatology's efficacy in both a simulated and real world environment and compare the audio and visual fidelity of both low and higher cost technologies in the context of teleneonatal resuscitation.
The objective of this aim is to utilize randomized trial design to compare teleneonatal to bedside resuscitation. We hypothesize that resuscitation facilitated with teleneonatology but not performed by an experienced care provider is noninferior to bedside resuscitation performed by an experienced care provider.

primary_outcome.description: The proportion of time for which the mannequin received no effective ventilation (the number of seconds without effective ventilation divided by the total number of seconds)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 30 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: The warmer turned on, the infant dried with a towel, and then stimulated either by rubbing the back or patting the foot.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time of first heart rate check (seconds)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline until heart rate check up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the heart rate was first checked either by stethoscope, palpation of umbilical stump, or by EKG lead.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 60 seconds up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: HR was checked within 60 seconds after birth.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to bag mask placement up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the mask was first applied to the infant's face.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: Mask was applied to the infant's face at 60 seconds after birth.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to probe placement up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the oxygen saturation probe was placed.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: Sat probe placed at 60 seconds after birth.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From simulation start to time of FiO2 increase up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the amount of oxygen administered was increased.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Mask was adjusted on the infant's face

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: infant's neck was adjusted

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: infant's mouth was suctioned

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: infant's mouth was opened

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: pressure on bag mask was increased

secondary_outcome.measure: MR SOPA Performance: Placed advanced airway
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: endotracheal tube was placed

secondary_outcome.measure: MR SOPA performed in correct sequence
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: corrective measures were performed in this sequence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: each corrective measure was performed

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of bag mask ventilation to 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of steps correctly performed during the resuscitation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of bag mask placement until chest rise up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the mannequin had visible chest rise

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline until first compression up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The number of seconds elapsed at the time the first chest compression was performed

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline until first compression up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Either two fingers on the mannequin's sternum or thumbs over the sternum with hands encircling the chest

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline until first compression up to 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: 1/3 of the infant's chest depth

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start time of compression until 60 seconds have elapsed
secondary_outcome.description: The number of compressions performed in the first 60 seconds from the start of chest compressions

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start time of compression until 60 seconds have elapsed
secondary_outcome.description: Check "Yes" if 100-120 compressions performed per minute for the first minute

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start time of compression until 60 seconds have elapsed
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of time for which the mannequin received no effective compression (the number of seconds without effective chest compressions divided by the total number of seconds)

arm_group.description: Experienced provider and nurse will perform resuscitation
Trainee, teleneonatologist, and nurse will perform resuscitation
Trainee and nurse will perform resuscitation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Inclusion criteria for experienced providers include at least 3 years of pediatric and/or neonatal training, having previously performed >10 endotracheal intubations, and may include neonatologists, pediatric fellows, and neonatal nurse practitioners. Inclusion criteria for trainees: previous exposure to NRP, an interval of > 3 months elapsing between previous NRP applications, and may include pediatric residents, family medicine residents, nurses, respiratory therapists, neonatal fellows, and neonatal attendings.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Does not meet inclusion criteria
